course.subject: CIVL
course.name: Infrastructure Systems Engineering and Management
course.description: This course will cover basic principles and techniques for analyzing engineering systems. It will entail an introduction to linear programs, network analysis, critical path method, benefit-cost and present value analyses of engineering projects.

reviews.author: ChristopherWong
reviews.title: good grade course
reviews.comment_content:
Part 1:
1:Introduction to systems engineering and management
2:Properties of linear programs
3:Solving linear programs
4:Sensitivity analysis
5:Introduction to networks
6:Formulating and solving network problems
7:Engineering applications

Part 2:
1:Engineering, Business and Society
2:Introduction to Financial Management
3:Business Profitability Analysis
4:Time Value of Money
5:Discounted Cash Flow Method
6:Project Funding
7:Project Cash Flow Analysis

Both midterm and final test students with questions very similar to those in assignments so it is suggested to do revision on your assignments.
Content are actually kind of related more to business than engineering.
Totally speaking it is a good-grade course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
9am lecture so not many people have attended.Both lecturer have serious chinese accents which you may not be able to understand what they are saying(Zhang xue qing slightly better than yang hai).
Although both of them are willing and ambitious in teaching,their accents are the main reasons that very few student take the lectures,for only around 30 people over 140 in the whole class.
Not necessary to take the class,better to do self study .
reviews.comment_grading:
Part 1:50%
-Assignment/Quiz:10%
-Mid term:40%        (2-hour open Book exam) one a4 sized cheatsheet
Part 2:50%
-Assignment/Quiz:10%
-Final Exam:40%   (2-hour open Book exam) one a4 sized cheatsheet

Midterm:70/100
Final:Unknown
Grade:B+
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload actually very low, just 3 assignments before midterm(part one) . 2 assignments after midterm(part2) and it is done by a group of 3people which means the workload is further lower.
Coverage of test contents are not that much,just need to do revision 2-3 day before the exams.
Assignments are given one week to finish for those before midterm and 2-3 weeks for those after the midterm.
No sources for assignments so discuss with your classmates and make sure you get the highest mark you can because the mean for both midterm and final are quite high.

reviews.author: Frankie:)
reviews.title: Grading scheme is way better than CIVL2160
reviews.comment_content:
The first part of the course covers linear programming where the simplex-method with the use of Gaussian Elimination learnt back in MATH2350 will be used again here in this course. It seems that the general contents for this course have been detailly disclosed by others, so I wouldn't repeat it once again here.
The content is a bit light for a 3-credit course
reviews.comment_teaching: From my perspective, both professors were not native-English speakers, local students may have difficulties in understanding their English accent.
reviews.comment_grading:
For the grading,it is very very lenient and good.Don't worry if you only got above mean by a few scores
I would like to talk about what types of questions appear in the Midterm and Final exam.
For Part 1:
There are a total of 4 questions in the midterm exam with 1hr15mins time limits given.
Regarding the first question, the questions ask to use the graphing method to solve linear inequality equations and converts the equation to general form
Regarding the second question, that was a Simplex method with tableau form question where u were asked to fill in the missing blanks in the tableau.
Regarding the third question, that was the shortest path problem which was rather straightforward and easy.
Regarding the last question, question 4, it tested your understanding of the simplex method with tableau form. The questions will ask u the concept of shadow price, the range of feasibility for the coefficient and the solution. (Sorry for forgetting the technical terminology used in this part)

Part2:
The Final exam for this part consists of 2 sessions.
Session 1: (45 mins)
MCQ and True/False Question, these questions were directly copied from the IPRS questions done in lecture time with being allowed to open-book, the mean is close to full marks. This part contained absolutely no brainer questions that u only need to DIRECT copy from the answer since the questions appeared in the exact same order as the answer given by the professor.
Sessions 2: (1 hr)
It consisted of 4 long questions, 2 of which were the calculation of monthly deposit and instalment. The third question was the graphing of the overdraft diagram and the last question is the income statement type question.
Conclusion:
As long as u don't give up and work hard before the will be rewarded a good grade.

My Scores:
Part 1 Exam: 78/100 Mean 75.7/100
Part 2 Exam: unknown score not given
Letter grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light,all the assignement were just direct copy from source given by the CIVIL society
U just need to revise a few days before the exam to get a good gradeğŸ˜
The workload is light compared to other CIVL 3-credit bearing course

reviews.author: smile slime
reviews.comment_content:
The whole course is separated into 2 parts
First half is taught by Prof Yang and second half is taught by Prof Zhang.
In the first half course, linear programming is the main topic.
In the second half, knowledge about accounting are taught like overdraft, montage and income statement.
reviews.comment_teaching: Someone may find both prof's English is not fluent and prefer self-study.  Therefore, only few people will attend lectures by both prof even if Prof Yang will randomly take attendance at the end of some lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Both midterm and final allow two-sided A4 cheatsheet.
Midterm
Average 71.37
SD 13.13
Final is not announced
I got 87/100 in MT, 95,100,100 in Assignment respectively
and finally get A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is not heavy at all.
Someone only focus on writing the cheat sheet and get quite a good result.
Also, there are lecture videos and Prof Yang emphasized that the attendance taken at the end of the lecture will not have great influence, so many people skip the classes.
But tutorial will take attendance by giving a quiz.

reviews.author: chpoonag
reviews.title: One careless move losses the whole game.
reviews.comment_content:
The course is divided into 2 parts.

1. Simplex method
You will learn simplex method which solves an objective function (maximizing or minimizing) with several constraints (some inequalities). Dijkstra's algorithm will also be taught to solve shortest path problems.

2. Business in Engineering
In this part, you will first learn some facts/backgrounds on why studying business in the first chapter, which will only be a minor component in this part of the course. Then, income statement, IRR, ERR, overdraft calculations and so on will be taught. These are the main topics. Note that the format of the income statement to be tested is simple. No categorization of expenses is needed in the exam but it may be required in assignments.

Some lecture videos of the second part of the course were provided since some students request for them (the professor thought the videos had been recorded automatically so only half of the lectures were recorded).

Note that the last lecture of the 2nd part of the course was very important as some questions discussed during that lecture were actually identical to those in the exam paper. There were few students attending the class, and at the same time, a number of them did not watch the lecture video of the last lecture. It significantly affected the grades of this course.

Exams for the 2 parts are separate, which means those tested in the 1st exam will not be tested again.
reviews.comment_teaching:
One fact is that there were few students attending the lectures (about 10 to 15 for the 2nd part lectures).
For Prof YANGâ€™s, there may be more students attending. Personally, it is just because of the difficulty of the topic (simplex method). However, most of the voices I heard said even attending the course cannot ensure you understand that. Firstly, his accent. Secondly, his explanation way. All in all, attending lectures may function as warning you that you should also learn yourself outside classroom instead. Personally, the only thing I hate most is his voice, which can be too loud suddenly.

For Prof ZHANGâ€™s, since they are morning lessons, his voice and his pace can make you fall asleep easily. In my opinion, the accent of both professors may be equally difficult for local (or even international students) to understand. Yet, after 1 to 2 weeks should you be able to get used to that.

There could be many aspects to complain about their teaching. Nevertheless, their passion in teaching and patience in explaining some questions to students should be appreciated.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% assignments
10% quizzes (just for attendance in the 1st part of the course but not sure about the 2nd part)
40% exam (1st part): 1 A4 printed/hand-written cheat sheet allowed
40% exam (2nd part): 1 A4 printed/hand-written cheat sheet allowed

Questions in the paper for the 1st part were similar to those in the assignments. One of the differences is that you did not need to write the entire iteration table (simplex method). We were just asked to fill in some blanks. However, the last question was really challenging. most of us just got 1-3 marks and only 1 or 2 students got over 10 marks out of 30 marks.

As most of the questions are â€œeasyâ€, the mean was quite high. Initially, the S.D. was large because there was one question about the shortest path that any wrong steps can preclude you from getting any more marks for subsequent steps for using the correct method. In the end, as there were a number of complaints, the marking scheme was revised, and most of us had our midterm grade improved.

In the 2nd part of the course, there T/F questions (10 marks, 2 points each), filling in the blanks (20 marks, 2 marks each), as well as typical calculation questions. As mentioned, one of the calculation questions were actually nearly identical to those discussed during the last lecture, so I guess some who had watched that lecture video / attended that lecture should have got a good result (30 marks for that â€œidenticalâ€ question). Another one of the questions was similar to one assignment questions (income statement) but the exam one was a simplified one with more hints. Also, some more different aspects were included in this question in attempt to include most of the contents in the examination scope (40 marks). The last calculation question was just the same as the one in the assignment (30 marks). It is about project cash flow/overdraft calculation.

Notice that there should be sources for the assignments in the 1st part of the course but none for the 2nd part. For those in the 2nd part, it was allowed to work in groups of a maximum of 3 to submit one single assignment. So, you may work with the others. Also, some questions were actually chosen from the reference books (similar to worked examples / from the exercise questions). If you want to ensure a good grade, homework of the 2nd part of the course should be paid more attention since the mean should be lower than those of the 1st part of the course.

To sum up, the exam in the 2nd part of the course should be also easy for most of us although there are one to two challenging questions. So, carefulness is the key to success in this course. One careless move losses the entire game.

Some data:
1st part
- Overall 37.9167/50 , mean 38.0700, sd 5.6918, median 39.0833
(Midterm 70/100, mean 71.374, sd 13.13)


2nd part
- Assignment 1: ?
- Assignment 2: 96/100, mean 86.1, high 98 low 10

I think I did much better in the last exam so it made me achieve an A- in the end.
reviews.comment_workload:
Manageable workload in my point of view.
1st part:
3 assignments
1 quiz for each tutorial class (once a week; taking attendance only)
2nd part:
2 assignments. You can work with 2 more students (optional) and hand in 1 copy.
2 quizzes (an email was sent prior to each quiz to remind students to attend the tutorial class)

reviews.author: SQ Flyer
reviews.title: Mathematical Modeling, Network Problem, Scheduling,TVM éå¸¸åˆç†Grading
reviews.comment_content:
The course is divided into two parts, Modelling and Management.
Non-cumulative.

Part I
Linear Programming and Mathematical Modelling
(Problem Statement and Graphical Method)
Simplex Method
Duality Problem-Sensitivity Analysis
Networking Problems

Part II
Work breakdown structure
Critical Path Method, Scheduling Problems
PERT Project Evaluation and Review Technique, Line of Balance
Time Value of Money
Present Worth Analysis
reviews.comment_teaching:
For Part I, Prof Jian is teaching this course for the first time. Initially, some may find the content hard to follow due to the clumsy iterative process for most of the problem set-up. However, she is able to demonstrate the concepts with clear step illustration in the notes and even work on some problems during classes. The assignments are properly designed which provide chances for us to do proper practices, though students need to revise the notes in detail for the repetitive iteration process in Simplex Method problem, Dijhastra Algorithm, duality problem etc. Overall, the topics I would say they are not difficult but need more attention on the problem statement and iteration process, one careless mistake may lead to heavy score loss in midterm exam.

For Part II, Prof Jack Cheng has a relatively slower teaching progress, he explains the concepts clearly with the aid of some in-class problems, the notes are presented to-the-point, illustrative and clear. The only bad thing is, his Konglish which maybe annoying sometimes.

For the tutorial part, I think they are not really important because they directly copy the content from the lecture notes and explain the completed assignments again during tutorials. Just look for some of the additional examples in the tutorial notes then that's fine. I remember one of the TAs prepared a script to read aloud in front of the camera, such a joke.
reviews.comment_grading:
50% for each part, 15% Assignment+ 35% Exam respectively, non-cumulative.

Due to the pandemic, the difficulty of the exams are relatively higher than that of the usual semester. Exam time are heavily restricted to 70 mins and 90 mins respectively, while the questions are designed to be very clumsy with very long steps, although they are indeed not difficult in terms of the content. You need to work really fast and precise to get most of the score even you really know the techniques.

For Part I, all long questions with problem statement set-up, simplex method,  graphical method, duality problem, shortest path problem etc.

Mean: 23.9/35
Max: 35/35 crazy

For Part II,  5 MCQs, short questions (explaining the definitions etc), 3 huge LQs. The professor has designed three versions of paper to avoid cheating. The questions are clumsy though manageable if you work fast and precise.

LQs:
1. CPM with AOA transformation, EST/EFT, PERT analysis --> an advantage for students who took IEDA 2200 before, you should have mastered the skills already.

2. Time Value of Money
3. Present Worth Analysis

Mean:21.9/35 (pretty low due to time constraint)
Max 30.8/35


Personal Result:  
PART I: Assignment 13.5/15, Exam 29/35
PART II: Assignment 15/15, Exam 26/35
Overall 83.5%
Grade: A (nice grading)

Just work fast and precise during exams if you want good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
For Part I, the workload is relatively higher, we have a total of 4 weekly assignments covering the topics for the last week. Some of them may need more time to be completed due to the heavy iterative process.
We got a mock exam and a self-practice before the midterm as aids for preparation.
Part I requires more revision time due to the many different types of problem statement and solving techniques. They are not difficult but just clumsy.

For Part II, only two simple assignments. Revise the note examples and concepts with clear understanding then it should be fine for the exam.

Reference textbook:
Civil & Environmental Systems Engineering from Prentice Hill
Basics of Engineering Economy from McGraw Hill
Operation Research from McGraw Hill

reviews.author: Watermelon
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1: Introduction to Systems Engineering and Management
Chapter 2: Introduction to Linear Programs
Chapter 3: Properties of Linear Programs
Chapter 4: Solving Linear Programs:
- Part 1: Simplex Method
- Part 2: Simplex Method with Tableau Form
Chapter 5: Simplex-Based Sensitivity Analysis
Chapter 6: Introduction to Network and Transportation Problem
Chapter 7: Formulating and Solving Network Flow Problems
Chapter 8: Civil Engineering Applications
///
Chapter 9: Project Planning, Work Breakdown Structure, and Work Sequence
Chapter 10: Project Scheduling Using Critical Path Method (CPM)
Chapter 11: PERT Networks
Chapter 12: Linear Construction Operations and Line of Balance
Chapter 13: Time Value of Money
Chapter 14: Financial Comparison and Economic Analysis of Engineering Systems Using Present Worth Analysis
Chapter 15: Payback Period
Chapter 16: Financial Comparison and Economic Analysis of Engineering Systems Using Rate of Return Analysis
Chapter 17: Risk and Uncertainty Analysis
reviews.comment_grading:
Part 1 (50%):
- Assignments: 15%
- Midterm: 35%

Part 2 (50%):
- Assignments: 15%
- Final: 35%

/

Part 1:
- Assignments: 14.3 / 15 (mean:12.84)
- Midterm: 35 / 35 (mean: 22.3)

Part 2:
- Assignments: 14.1 / 15 (mean: 12.87)
- Final: (unknown)

Overall: A

reviews.author: drew.ng
reviews.title: Sisi > Jack
reviews.comment_content: I forgot what the contents were but theyre all calculation based. I'm sure the other reviews help.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Sisi is one of the better professors in terms of teaching. Her english is alright but the fact that shes willing to answer any/all questions even when someone types some dumb shit makes it very enjoyable. She can understand your question very quickly and is able to answer it and explain it, she'll make sure you know whats going on before moving on.

Jack graduated from UST and as a UST student, his strict, no-nonsense and irresponsive teaching style is expected but boy, are my expectations low. He loves to make you draw your own diagrams even when we're online (????? why ?????). His presentations are poor and he just annotates over them - if you miss a lecture, get ready to be bent over and f*cked.
reviews.comment_grading: Good grading but very competitive since it is mostly mathematics. SD was tight but the average was B.
reviews.comment_workload: Assignments once per week (I never wore a seatbelt when I drive because it would be easier to end it like this). Sisi's lecture slides were hella clear so missing the first half of the semester was ok. But boy, Jack set the bar so low an ant couldnt limbo under it. His lecture slides are basically empty and copied and pasted diagrams dont help. He writes on them so youre gonna have to be very quick to follow.

reviews.author: Lugia
reviews.comment_content:
Consider this course as an introductory for transportation engineering and construction management. It is divided into 2 parts, which everything before the mid-term will focus on the transportation part, and everything after will focus on the management part.

For the Transportation part,
1. Simplex method
2. Shortest path

For the Management part,
1. Reasons for studying Bussiness as an Engineering
2. Accounting
3. Time Value of Money
4. Discounted Cash Flow Method
5. Project Funding
6. Project Cash Flow.

* The syllabus may change year by year.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Who goes to school at 9 am...........
Luckily both profs upload lecture videos.

But, I can't understand Prof. Yang's accent, even in the lecture video...........

I don't understand why people are giving so much sheet for Prof. Zhang's accent, personally, I can understand him completely fine.

To me, any course that provides lecture videos deserves a B.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% Assignments and Quizzes (10% each for part 1 and 2)
40% Mid-term
40% Final

Got an A.
All I can say is, it is definitely because I worked really hard in this course. Surely isn't because of the prof's lenient grading, which somehow magically caused me to end up with this grade, despite having a mediocre mid-term score. Yup! It is all on me.
reviews.comment_workload:
Near to none.
Assignments in part 1 are easy.
You can do it in groups for assignments in part 2.
Check your answers with other classmates/ groups before handing in.
Remember to attend the tutorial for the quizzes.

reviews.author: USTheagod
reviews.comment_content:
-have no idea why we are learning all these craps but at least it's better than CIVL2160 lol
-homeworks in the second half of the course are very poorly designed...
reviews.comment_teaching: it's a 9am lecture plus the profs' accents are too difficult to understand so I almost skipped all the lectures :((((((((
reviews.comment_workload:
-no workload at all...
-you just need to attend tutorials for the quiz
-you can work with your friends for the assignments in the second half of the course so make sure you find a hokba to help you lmao
-exams are all about cheatsheets.
